defining-lists_key2: To define lists we can use `square brackets` - `[]`.
defining-lists_key3: Whenever you see `[`, then think that list definition has started, and when you see `]`, then think that list definition is ending.
defining-lists_key5: In this example, we will store the names of students in a list.
defining-lists_key6: In the last line, we have used `type ()`. By using this function we will come to know that what is its data type.
defining-lists_key7: This is the `list of `strings`` because all of its values contain `strings`.
defining-lists_key8: **Please note that to start a `List`, `[` is used and to close `]` is used. `[]` looks like a square shape, that is why these are called `SQUARE BRACKETS`.**
defining-lists_key9: We can put any object inside a `list`. This can be `string, `integer`` or any other data type.
defining-lists_key11: This is the listof some bank names.
defining-lists_key13: This is the list of a student's marks.
defining-lists_key15: This is the list of temperatures for the last seven days.
defining-lists_key16: But if we will use the type function on a list `variable`, it will always show the type as a list. But the data inside a list can be of any type.
defining-lists_key19: Make a `list` of all the countries that you want to visit.
defining-lists_key20: Make a list of `total expenses` of last 5 months (suppose, your last month's expenses were 58750 and so on.)
